def get_sneaker_data(base_url, page_number):
    url = f"{base_url}?page={page_number}“
    response = requests.get(url)
    soup = BeautifulSoup(response.content, ‘html.parser’)

    sneaker_data = []

    for product in soup.find_all(‘div’, class_=‘productgrid–item’):
        name = product.find(‘div’, class_=‘product_item–title’).text.strip()
        price = product.find(‘div’, class_=‘price_item–regular’).text.strip()
        link = product.find(‘a’, class_='productgrid–imglink’)[‘href’]
        sneaker_data.append((name, price, link))

    return sneaker_data

Jazib Magnet Indicator makes use of the Simple Moving Average (SMA), Relative Strength Index (RSI), and Stochastic Oscillator, three straightforward indicators. This indicator provides traders a trusted and user-friendly way to make informed market judgements with a 100% no-repaint and a 3 to 4 minute expiry.

Binary Options MT4 only uses manual processes. The indicators generate the signals, but it is up to the trader to decide when to enter the market, create protective stops, and when to quit it profitably. As a result, the trader must be conversant with the concepts of risk and reward and set entries and exits using initial support and resistance levels.

This Jazib Trading Indicator can provide trading signals that you can use as-is or combine with other chart analysis to further filter. All levels of traders can utilise this strategy, however until you are reliable and self-assured enough to trade on a live account, it can be helpful to practise trading on an MT4 demo account.

This indicator is completely free and unrestricted by the JAZIB TRADING VIP telegram channel. Their primary objective is to offer superior signal bots, software, and free techniques. Therefore, give the JAZIB TRADING VIP telegram channel some love.

The primary chart for this MT4 indicator for binary options.

Fig. 1, 2, and 3 (Above Image).

Simple to use, this Jazib Magnet Indicator. When a new signal emerges, you'll receive a signal alert. This is advantageous since it allows you to keep an eye on numerous charts at once rather than having to spend the entire day waiting for signals to come on the charts.

Any Forex currency pair as well as other assets including stocks, commodities, cryptocurrencies, precious metals, oil, gas, etc. can be traded using the Jazib Trading Indicator. Additionally, you may apply it to any time frame that works best for you, including charts for one minute to one month.

the Jazib Magnet Indicator's method for producing signals.

By combining the strength of three widely used technical indicators—the SMA, RSI, and Stochastic Oscillator—the Binary Options MT4 creates indications for both buying and selling binary options contracts. The buy and sell signals are determined as follows:

Sell Signal.

The price of the asset must be lower than the SMA 150, a popular technical indicator that determines the average price of an asset over a given time period (in this example, 150 periods).
The asset may be cheap and a price reversal may be on the horizon if the RSI (3) is in the oversold zone (less than 20).
A decrease in selling pressure and a potential price increase are indicated by the Stochastic Oscillator (6, 3, and 3), which should also be in the oversold region (less than 20).
Buy Signal:

To produce a purchase signal, the Jazib Trading Indicator searches for the circumstances that are the opposite of those for a sale signal.
The price of the asset must be higher than the SMA 150, signifying a bullish trend.
The asset may be overvalued and a price reversal may be on the horizon if the RSI (3) is in the overbought zone (higher than 80).
The Stochastic Oscillator (6, 3, 3) should be over 80, indicating overbought conditions, which suggests that price declines may be imminent when purchasing pressure declines.
Trading Guidelines for the Jazib Indicator.

Give me a summary for the following essay: •	International Segmentation and Targeting strategy – POINT 6

	Stage 1: Market Segmentation

In the first stage, El-Wahy will identify different segments within the Tunisian market. Some potential segments include:

1. Expatriate Egyptians living in Tunisia who might be seeking a taste of home.
2. Local Tunisians who enjoy trying various international cuisines, especially Middle Eastern cuisines similar to their own.
3. Tourists from Egypt as well as other countries who are interested in trying authentic Egyptian food.
4. Business clientele and local companies looking for a unique dining experience for meetings or events.

Stage 2: Market Targeting

El-Wahy should adopt a differentiated marketing strategy, in which different marketing mixes are designed for each segment. The rationale for choosing this strategy is to cater to the unique needs of each segment and provide a more personalized experience for customers, ultimately leading to higher customer satisfaction and loyalty.

Segment 1: Expatriate Egyptians
El-Wahy should target this segment by offering authentic Egyptian dishes and traditional flavors. Marketing efforts should emphasize nostalgia and the connection to Egypt. Strategies could include targeted social media and outreach through Egyptian community associations in Tunisia.

Segment 2: Local Tunisians
El-Wahy should target this segment by showcasing the diverse menu and unique Egyptian flavors. The restaurant can emphasize the use of fresh and high-quality ingredients. Marketing efforts may include local TV ads, billboards, and food events.

Segment 3: Tourists
This segment can be targeted by promoting the unique dining experience and the opportunity to try traditional Egyptian cuisine. Collaborations with tour operators and hotels in Tunisia can help in attracting tourists to the restaurant.

Segment 4: Business clientele and local companies
El-Wahy should offer both on-site and off-site services for this segment, such as private dining rooms and catering. The restaurant can tailor its menu offerings to accommodate specific business preferences and budgets. Networking events and partnerships with local business organizations can help tap into this market.

Stage 3: Market Positioning
Having chosen the segments to target, El-Wahy must create a clear and unique brand image in the minds of customers from each segment. For expatriates and tourists, the positioning should emphasize the authenticity and connection to Egypt. For local Tunisians and business clientele, the focus should be on the unique dining experience, high-quality ingredients, and excellent customer service.

In conclusion, adopting a differentiated marketing strategy will allow El-Wahy to effectively cater to the different needs of each segment within the Tunisian market, leading to increased customer satisfaction and ultimately, business success.

          .Royal Assent. Having passed the House of Lords the Bill is ready for the Royal Assent, which may be given by the Queen personally or by three Lords Commissioners. The Royal Assent Act, 1967, now provides that an Act is duly enacted if the Royal Assent is notified to each House of Parliament, sitting separately, by either the Speaker of that House or the act- ing Speaker. The Royal Assent is now simply a formality. Once the Royal Assent is given, the Bill becomes an Act of Parliament and takes effect imme- diately (unless some future date is specified in the Act).
Private Members' Bills. At the beginning of a Parliamentary Session (a session lasts one year), the Cabinet lays down its legislative programme. It is still possible for a Private Member of the House (i.e. an M.P. who is not a member of the Government) to introduce a Bill on some matter of import- ance to him or her. If the Private Member's Bill is of general importance and receives the support of the House it may be adopted by the Government and so form part of its legislative programme. Otherwise the Member may have difficulty in securing the passage of the Bill through Parliament. The Matrimonial Causes Act, 1937, and the Murder (Abolition of Death Penalty) Act, 1965, were the Private Members' Bills of Sir Alan Herbert and Mr Sidney Silverman, respectively.
Private Bills. These are of two kinds: (i) Local and (ii) Personal.
Local Bills deal with purely local matters. Where a local authority or other public body wishes to acquire additional powers not available under the gen- eral law, it may obtain them by the promotion of a private Bill. After receiving Parliament's approval the Bill becomes an Act of Parliament. Local Bills usu- ally deal with the construction or alteration of bridges, canals, docks, ports, roads, railways, tramways, waterworks, etc., or with extending the powers of local authorities, gas, electricity or other public-utility undertakings.
Personal Bills relate to private estates, names, naturalization, divorce, peerage and other matters. Such Bills are rare and must be started in the House of Lords.
Conflict with Common Law. Because Parliament is omnipotent in the field of law, it follows that a statute may abolish any rule of common law or criminal offence at common law. any

Companies need to create quarterly and annual reports on how their company is doing which are presented to people like the board of directors and the shareholders.  You (and a partner if you would like) are going to create a presentation that reports on the performance of a fictional company that you are going to create.

Plan it with the idea that the chairman of the board (me) is going to look at it by myself without the aid of someone explaining or narrating the slides.  Therefore the presentation needs to be complete on its own.  At the same time you want it to be interesting to look at, and not too text-heavy to keep the viewer interested.

	Purpose:  Demonstrate understanding of the principles of demand and supply discussed in chapters 4 and 5.
	How:  Create graphs and tables illustrating things like total demand, total supply, change in supply, change in quantity demanded, etc.
	How (part 2):  Create a fictional company and make fictional charts showing (realistically) fictional supply and demand principles.

Guidelines:  The company can make anything you want, but just remember this is a family friendly class.  
	Keep things in relative scale--you can have a small business or you can have a huge company.  But the numbers should reflect a small business (lower quantities, dollar figures, etc.) or a larger business (thousands of units sold or made, big cost and profit numbers).
	You will need to account for changes in supply and demand.  You will recall that there are a number of things that can change both.  You will need to explain what happened to create the change that is shown on the schedule (table) or the graph.

So...You are going to create your own example of each of the concepts listed below in #2-9
	All the examples are of the company you’ve created, and the examples and your explanations create a narrative story of how your company is doing.

The different parts of your presentation:

 The introduction--A short description of what your company does and where it is located.
Supply curves:  Show the supply curve or schedule of your company, your only competitor, and the entire market (you and your competitor)
Changes in Supply:  Show the change in supply that occurred and describe two reasons for it.  (Explain what happened to create the change. (Ex: Tariffs on the imported material used to make your product went up causing a shift in supply, while productivity went down due to the pandemic)   So the graph or table will show the before and after of the shift.
Elasticity/Inelasticity:  Show the price shift of your product at different prices and describe how elastic or inelastic it is, and also give a reason for this.
Short-Run Production:  Show the short-run production changes as you add or decrease your staff.  Explain why this was done.
Production, Cost, and Revenue:  Create a production, costs, and revenue chart (such as can be found on p. 134).   Your chart need not be so extensive as the textbook example, Include three levels for stage 1, and one each for stages 2 and 3.  (You can leave out marginal cost and marginal revenue.)
	Explain what your going to do in the future given what the chart is telling you--higher more people, cut people, lower fixed costs (how), 

 Market Demand Curve:  create a market demand curve for your product, AND describe who/what is the main market for your product.
Change in Demand Curve:  show the change in demand you anticipate happening next year, OR happened from the previous year.  Explain why that occurred.(what caused the change in demand?
Demand elasticity:  Discuss the degree to which the demand for your product is elastic.
Conclusion:  What are the prospects for your company in the coming year?  Will it flourish and grow like Amazon, or go the way of compact disc makers?


When finished you will have demonstrated all the economic principles of the last two chapters.  It is hoped that you will show some creativity along the way in the fortunes of your company and the reasons for its success or failure during the previous year. (Assuming you’re creating the annual report for the company.

(In the school literature clubroom…)

Monika: “Natsuki, are you alright? You know you shouldn’t be attending club meetings at 7 months pregnant!”

Natsuki: (sighs) “I know, Monika, but I can’t just miss out on everything. I want to be here with everyone.”

Yuri: “I understand your enthusiasm, Natsuki, but it’s important to prioritize your health and the well-being of your daughter. Maybe taking a break would be beneficial for both of you?”

Natsuki: “I’ve been feeling fine so far, and the doctor said it’s okay for me to continue my normal activities. I just need to take it easy.”

Sayori: “Natsuki, I’m worried about you too. You’re important to us, and we want to make sure you and Sakura are doing well.”

Natsuki: “Thank you, Sayori. I appreciate your concern, but I promise I’ll take care of myself. And besides, being here with all of you brings me joy and helps me relax.”

Monika: “I understand that, Natsuki, but we also want you to prioritize your health. Maybe we can come up with a plan that allows you to still be involved in the club while also taking it easy.”

Yuri: “That’s a good idea, Monika. We can delegate some tasks to Natsuki that don’t require too much physical exertion. That way, she can still participate and feel included without overexerting herself.”

Natsuki: “That sounds fair. I don’t want to feel left out, but I also don’t want to put myself or Sakura at risk. Maybe I can help with organizing club events or handling some paperwork, things like that. As long as it doesn’t require too much physical effort, I think it should be fine.”

Sayori: “That sounds like a good plan, Natsuki. We’ll make sure to distribute tasks evenly and ensure that you’re not overwhelmed. We’ll all be here to support you every step of the way.”

Monika: “Absolutely. Your health and well-being are important to us, Natsuki. We want you to know that we value you and your contributions to the club, but we also want to make sure you and Sakura are taken care of.”

Yuri: “Indeed. We can make some adjustments to our club activities and schedule to accommodate your needs. We’ll make sure you have enough rest and aren’t overwhelmed with responsibilities.”

Natsuki: “Thank you, everyone. I really appreciate your understanding and support. I want to continue being an active member of this club, and I know I can rely on all of you to help me do that while still taking care of myself and Sakura.”

Sayori: “Of course, Natsuki. We’re all in this together, and we’ll make sure you have the support and care you need. We’ll find a balance that works for everyone.”

Natsuki: (her hands close to her belly) “Aah!”

(In the cavern where the Mana Spirits live…)

Wisp: (waking up) “Good morning, fellow Mana Spirits!”

Gnome: “Well…it’s better than getting eaten by Jewel Eater!”

Jinn: “Man, I slept good!”

Shade: “Ugh…five more minutes.”

Undine: “Well, that was refreshing.”

Salamander: “Let’s get this started! I’m ready to TURN UP THE HEAT!!!”

Luna: (still snoring due to how far along she is in her pregnancy)

Dryad: “Is she always this sleepy?”

Wisp: “Well, she’s carrying the next generation of Mana Spirits, so I guess it’s understandable for her to be tired.”

Gnome: “Yeah, being a pregnant Mana Spirit must be exhausting.”

Jinn: “We should let her rest, she needs all the energy she can get.”

Shade: “Agreed. Luna has an important role to play. We should take care of her.”

Undine: “Let’s make sure she’s comfortable and has everything she needs.”

Salamander: “And once she wakes up, we’ll make sure she’s well-fed. She needs all the nutrients for the little ones.”

Dryad: “I’ll gather some soothing herbs and create a calm atmosphere for her.”

Wisp: “Sounds like a plan, everyone. Let’s take care of Luna and make sure she’s comfortable during this crucial time.”

(They all work together to create a peaceful and restful environment for Luna, making sure she has everything she needs. They understand the importance of her role in continuing the cycle of Mana Spirits. But just a few minutes later…)

Luna: (waking up to pain in her belly) “Ah…! Ah…!”

Wisp: “Luna, are you alright? What’s happening?”

Gnome: “Is everything okay with the baby?”

Luna: (grimacing) “I… I think… it’s time… the little ones are coming…”

Jinn: “Oh, no! We need to get her help immediately!”

Shade: “I’ll go find the Great Tree. It might have healing powers or someone who can assist us.”

Undine: “And I’ll gather water to help ease the pain. Stay strong, Luna.”

Salamander: “I’ll create a protective barrier around her to ensure her safety.”

Dryad: “I’ll stay by her side and offer any assistance she needs.”

Wisp: “Everyone, let’s act quickly and efficiently. Luna and her babies rely on us.”

(The Mana Spirits quickly spring into action, utilizing their powers and resources to support Luna through her labor. They create a warm and soothing atmosphere, with healing magic and calming presence. Eventually, Luna starts to push.)

2. We don't have a solution for the problem. We have some ideas for minimizing it, but the problem isn't going away. Detectors are unreliable. Pay-to-submit sacrifices too many legit authors. Print submissions are not viable for us.

Feb 21
3. Various third-party tools for identity confirmation are more expensive than magazines can afford and tend to have regional holes. Adopting them would be the same as banning entire countries.
clarkesworld
@clarkesworld
Feb 21
4. We could easily implement a system that only allowed authors that had previously submitted work to us. That would effectively ban new authors, which is not acceptable. They are an essential part of this ecosystem and our future.

create a dockerfile based on this scriptimport os
import json
import undetected_chromedriver as uc
from selectorlib import Extractor
import csv
import urllib.parse
import logging
from tqdm import tqdm
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor

def setup_directories_and_files():
    # Define the directories and files
    config_dir = './data/config'
    urls_dir = './data/urls'
    templates_dir = './data/templates'
    results_dir = './data/results'
    uc_settings_file = os.path.join(config_dir, 'uc_settings.txt')
    script_settings_file = os.path.join(config_dir, 'script_settings.txt')
    urls_list_file = os.path.join(urls_dir, 'urls_list.txt')
    urls_completed_file = os.path.join(urls_dir, 'urls_completed.txt')
    urls_failed_file = os.path.join(urls_dir, 'urls_failed.txt')

    # Create the directories if they do not exist
    os.makedirs(config_dir, exist_ok=True)
    os.makedirs(urls_dir, exist_ok=True)
    os.makedirs(templates_dir, exist_ok=True)
    os.makedirs(results_dir, exist_ok=True)

    return config_dir, urls_dir, templates_dir, results_dir, uc_settings_file, script_settings_file, urls_list_file, urls_completed_file, urls_failed_file

config_dir, urls_dir, templates_dir, results_dir, uc_settings_file, script_settings_file, urls_list_file, urls_completed_file, urls_failed_file = setup_directories_and_files()

# Set up logging
logging.basicConfig(filename='scraping.log', level=logging.INFO, format='%(asctime)s %(levelname)s:%(message)s')
console = logging.StreamHandler()
console.setLevel(logging.INFO)
formatter = logging.Formatter('%(asctime)s %(levelname)s:%(message)s')
console.setFormatter(formatter)
logging.getLogger('').addHandler(console)

error_logger = logging.getLogger('error_logger')
error_handler = logging.FileHandler('errors.log')
error_formatter = logging.Formatter('%(asctime)s %(levelname)s:%(message)s')
error_handler.setFormatter(error_formatter)
error_logger.addHandler(error_handler)
error_logger.setLevel(logging.ERROR)

# Create the files if they do not exist
for file in [uc_settings_file, script_settings_file, urls_list_file, urls_completed_file, urls_failed_file]:
    if not os.path.exists(file):
        open(file, 'w').close()

# Read the settings from the uc_settings.txt and script_settings.txt files
with open(uc_settings_file, 'r') as file:
    uc_settings = file.read().splitlines()

with open(script_settings_file, 'r') as file:
    script_settings = file.read().splitlines()

# Read the list of URLs from the urls_list.txt file
with open(urls_list_file, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as file:
    urls_list = file.read().splitlines()

def initialize_driver():
    # Initialize undetected-chromedriver
    options = uc.ChromeOptions()
    options.add_argument('--headless')
    options.add_argument('--window-size=800,600')
    options.add_argument('--window-position=0,0')
    options.add_argument("--disable-blink-features=AutomationControlled")
    options.add_argument("--disable-plugins-discovery")
    options.add_argument('--no-first-run')
    options.add_argument('--no-service-autorun')
    options.add_argument('--no-default-browser-check')
    options.add_argument('--window-position=0,0')
    options.add_argument("--disable-extensions")
    options.add_argument("--disable-notifications")
    options.add_argument('--no-sandbox')
    options.add_argument('--ignore-certificate-errors')
    options.add_argument('--disable-dev-shm-usage')
    options.add_experimental_option(
        "prefs",
        {
            "credentials_enable_service": False,
            "profile.password_manager_enabled": False,
            "autofill.profile_enabled": False,
        },
    )
    for setting in uc_settings:
        options.add_argument(setting)
    import shutil

    driver = uc.Chrome(options=options)
    return driver

def load_template(domain):
    # Initialize selectorlib
    template_file = os.path.join(templates_dir, f'{domain}.yml')
    if os.path.exists(template_file):
        logging.info(f'Template exists for domain: {domain}')
        e = Extractor.from_yaml_file(template_file)
        return e
    else:
        logging.warning(f'Template does not exist for domain: {domain}. Skipping URL: {url}')
        return None

def scrape_data(driver, e, url):
    driver.get(url)
    data = e.extract(driver.page_source)
    logging.info(f'Extracted data: {data}')
    # Close the driver
    driver.quit()
    return data

def save_data(data, domain):
    # Save the extracted data to {domain}_results.txt
    with open(os.path.join(results_dir, f'{domain}_results.txt'), 'a') as file:
        file.write(json.dumps(data) + '\n')

def scrape_url(url):
    logging.info(f'Starting to scrape URL: {url}')
    domain = urllib.parse.urlparse(url).netloc.split('.')[-2:-1][0]
    driver = initialize_driver()
    e = load_template(domain)
    if e is not None:
        try:
            data = scrape_data(driver, e, url)
            if data is not None:
                save_data(data, domain)
                logging.info(f'Successfully scraped URL: {url}')
                return data
        except Exception as e:
            error_logger.error(f'Error occurred while scraping URL {url}: {e}')
    return None
# Scrape the URLs sequentially
logging.info('Starting to scrape URLs sequentially')
for url in urls_list:
    result = scrape_url(url)
    if result:
        with open(urls_completed_file, 'a', encoding='utf-8') as file:
            if url.isascii():
                file.write(url + '\n')
                logging.info(f'Moved URL to urls_completed.txt: {url}')
            else:
                logging.warning(f'Skipped non-ASCII URL: {url}')
        urls_list.remove(url)
    else:
        with open(urls_failed_file, 'a', encoding='utf-8') as file:
            if url.isascii():
                file.write(url + '\n')
                logging.info(f'Moved URL to urls_failed.txt: {url}')
            else:
                logging.warning(f'Skipped non-ASCII URL: {url}')
        urls_list.remove(url)
logging.info('Finished scraping URLs sequentially')

# Handle errors gracefully and continue with the next URL if an error occurs
import time
import random
for url in urls_list:
    result = scrape_url(url)
    # Add a delay between each request to avoid being blocked by the server
    try:
        min_delay, max_delay = map(int, script_settings)
        time.sleep(random.uniform(min_delay, max_delay))
    except ValueError:
        error_logger.error("Error: script_settings contains invalid values")
    except Exception as e:
        error_logger.error(f'Error occurred: {e}')

Monika: “Alright, Natsuki! It’s your turn to share your poem!” (turning towards Natsuki - who is clutching her swollen belly in pain.) “…Natsuki?”

Natsuki: (winces and takes a deep breath) “I-I’m sorry, Monika. I…I don’t think I can read my poem right now. I’m in a lot of pain.”

Yuri: (concerned) “Natsuki, are you okay? Should we call a teacher or the nurse?”

Natsuki: (gritting her teeth) “No, it’s…it’s nothing serious. Just…some stomach cramps. They come and go. I hope Sakura’s okay…I’m only 7 months pregnant, so it’s still too early.”

Sayori: (looking worried) “Are you sure, Natsuki? We should get you some help. Maybe you need to lie down or something.”

Monika: (placing a hand on Natsuki’s shoulder) “Sayori’s right, Natsuki. We should make sure you’re okay. Your health and Sakura’s well-being comes first.”

Natsuki: (teary-eyed) “I know, but I don’t want to cause a fuss. I’ll be alright, really. It’s just a little discomfort.”

Yuri: (gentle tone) “Natsuki, please don’t worry about causing a fuss. We care about you, and we want you and Sakura to be safe. Let us help you.”

Sayori: (nodding) “Yuri’s right, Natsuki. We’re here for you. Let’s at least go to the nurse’s office and see what they say. It’s better to be safe than sorry-”

(All of a sudden, Natsuki’s water breaks, and she gasps in pain.)

Exercise 1: The Principles of Microeconomics
1.  The phenomenon of scarcity stems from the fact that 
a.	most economies’ production methods are not very good.
b.	in most economies, wealthy people consume disproportionate quantities of goods and services.
c.	governments restrict production of too many goods and services.
d.	resources are limited.
2. Which of the following statements best represents the principle represented by the adage, "There is no such thing as a free lunch"?
a.	Melissa can attend the concert only on Mondays.
b.	Greg is hungry and homeless.
c.	Brian rides his bike every day to class.
d.	Kendra must decide between going to Colorado or Cancun for spring break.
3. You have driven 500 miles on a vacation and then you notice that you are only 25 miles from an attraction you hadn’t known about, but would really like to see.  In computing the opportunity cost of visiting this attraction you had not planned to visit, you should include
a.	both the cost of driving the first 500 and the next 25 miles.
b.	the cost of driving the first 500 miles, but not the cost of driving the next 25.
c.	the cost of driving the next 25 miles, but not the cost of driving the first 500.
d.	neither the cost of driving the first 500 miles nor the cost of driving the next 25 miles.
4. The marginal benefit Colin gets from eating a fourth slice of pizza is
a.	the total benefit Colin gets from eating four slices of pizza minus the total benefit Colin gets from eating three slices of pizza.
b.	the same as the total benefit of eating four slices of pizza.
c.	less than the marginal cost of eating the fourth slice of pizza since he chose to eat the fourth slice.
d.	the total benefit Colin gets from eating five slices of pizza minus the total benefit Colin gets from eating four slices of pizza.
5. Senator Bright, who understands economic principles, is trying to convince workers in her district that trade with other countries is beneficial. Senator Bright should argue that trade can be beneficial
a.	only if it allows us to obtain things that we couldn't make for ourselves.
b.	because it allows specialization, which increases total output.
c.	to us if we can gain and the others involved in the trade lose.
d.	in only a limited number of circumstances because others are typically self-interested.
6. In an economy in which decisions are guided by prices and individual self-interest, there is
a.	a good potential to achieve efficiency in production.
b.	a strong need for government intervention in the market.
c.	less efficiency than would be observed in a centrally-planned economy.
d.	more need for a strong legal system to control individual greed than would be needed in a centrally-planned economy.

7. Thousands of people develop lung cancer from second-hand exposure to cigarette smoke.  This is an example of
a.	a market failure caused by an externality.
b.	a market failure caused by market power.
c.	a market failure caused by equality.
d.	There is no market failure in this case.
8. Denise decides to spend three hours working overtime rather than watching a video with her friends. She earns $10 an hour. Her opportunity cost of working is
a.	the $30 she earns working.
b.	the $30 minus the enjoyment she would have received from watching the video.
c.	the enjoyment she would have received had she watched the video.
d.	nothing, since she would have received less than $30 of enjoyment from the video.

require 'chunky_png'
class Color
  def initialize(color_table=nil)
    @color_table = color_table || [1, 0]
  end

  def rgb
    colors = [
      [[255,192,192], [255,0,0], [192,0,0]], # Red
      [[255,255,192], [255,255,0], [192,192,0]], # Yellow
      [[192,255,192], [0,255,0], [0,192,0]], # Green
      [[192,255,255], [0,255,255], [0,192,192]], # Cyan
      [[192,192,255], [0,0,255], [0,0,192]], # Blue
      [[255,192,255], [255,0,255], [192,0,192]], # Magenta
    ]
    colors[@color_table[1]][@color_table[0]]
  end

  def push_color
    @color_table[0] = (@color_table[0] + 1) % 3
    rgb
  end

  def write_color
    @color_table[0] = (@color_table[0] + 2) % 3
    @color_table[1] = (@color_table[1] + 5) % 6
    rgb
  end
end

  block = Array.new(12) { Array.new(12) { Array.new(3, 0) } }
  if num != 0
    old_push_color = current_color.push_color
    current_color.write_color

    block.each_index do |i|
      block[i].each_index do |j|
        block[i][j] = current_color.rgb
      end
    end
    block[0][0] = old_push_color
    size += 1
  else
    block.each_index do |i|
      block[i].each_index do |j|
        block[i][j] = current_color.rgb
      end
    end
  end

  pix_lft = 144 - size
  div = pix_lft / 12
  rem = pix_lft % 12

  if div != 0
    block[(12-div)..-1].each_index do |i|
      block[(12-div)..-1][i].each_index do |j|
        block[(12-div)+i][j] = [0,0,0]
      end
    end
  end
  block[(11-div)..-1].each_index do |i|
    block[(11-div)..-1][i][0...rem].each_index do |j|
      block[(11-div)+i][j] = [0,0,0]
    end
  end
  pos_y = 12 * num
  pos_x = 0
  piet_painting[pos_x...(pos_x+12)].each_index do |i|
    piet_painting[pos_x...(pos_x+12)][i][pos_y...(pos_y+12)].each_index do |j|
      piet_painting[pos_x+i][pos_y+j] = block[i][j]
    end
  end
end

def draw_end(piet_painting, current_color, num)
  block = Array.new(12) { Array.new(5) { Array.new(3, 255) } }

  old_push_color = current_color.push_color
  block[0][0] = old_push_color
  block[0][1] = current_color.write_color
  block[0...2].each_index do |i|
    block[i][3] = [0, 0, 0]
  end
  block[1][1] = [0, 0, 0]
  block[2][0] = [0, 0, 0]
  block[2][4] = [0, 0, 0]
  block[3][1...4].each_index do |i|
    block[3][i + 1] = [0, 0, 0]
  end
  c_color = current_color.write_color
  block[2][1...4].each_index do |i|
    block[2][i + 1] = c_color
  end
  pos_y = 12 * num
  pos_x = 0
  piet_painting[pos_x...(pos_x+12)].each_index do |i|
    piet_painting[pos_x...(pos_x+12)][i][pos_y...(pos_y+5)].each_index do |j|
      piet_painting[pos_x+i][pos_y+j] = block[i][j]
    end
  end
end

"Leviticus was written by the Zadokite priests left behind during the Babylonian Exile. It is essential a compendium of laws the Zadokites could salvage from the priesthood taken into exile. It could be assumed that they were written from a more conservative perspective to their contemporaries. Leviticus should not be read as the rulebook itself, but rather a book about some laws, rituals, and procedures from the First Temple period that the Zadokites wanted future generations to adhere to. The same can be said for sections of Exodus and Numbers that were written by the Priestly source. Deuteronomy was primarily written during and after the Babylonian Exile and set the legal standards during the Second Temple period and beyond. It could also be assumed that Deuteronomy was based on texts written by the Priestly source and shared the same conservative sentiment as the Priestly source authors, blaming the destruction of the First Temple and the Babylonian Exile on liberal sects that were not following the laws strictly enough."

After penetrating into the city [Carthage], Scipio [the Roman commander] turned his attention to the citadel, its strongest point, where many people had taken refuge. Three streets leading from the marketplace to the citadel were lined on both sides with six story houses, from which the Romans were pelted. They seized the first houses and used them as a base for attacking the next. From their roofs they made bridges of planks and beams to cross over to the next. While one battle was in progress on the roofs another was fought, against all comers, in the narrow street below. 

Everywhere there was groaning and wailing and shouting and agony of every description. Some Carthaginians were killed out of hand, some flung down alive from the roofs to the pavement, and of these some were caught on upright spears or ambers or swords…. 

Others were seen still living, especially old men, women, and young children who had hidden in the inmost corners of the houses, some of them wounded, some more or less burned, and uttering pitiful cries. Still others thrust out and falling from such a height with the stones, timbers, and fire, were torn asunder in all shapes of horror, crushed and mangled. 

Nor was this the end of their miseries, for the street cleaners, who were removing the rubbish with axes, mattocks, and forks, and making the roads passable, tossed with the dead and the living together into holes in the ground….

Six days and nights were consumed in this kind of fighting, the soldiers. Soldiers worked in shifts to ensure that that they might not be worn out with toil, slaughter, lack of sleep, and these horrid sights. 

The city of Carthage which had flourished for seven hundred years from its foundation, which had held broad dominion over lands and islands and seas, which had vied with the greatest of empires in its wealth of arms and ships and elephants and money, which had manifested extraordinary courage by resisting a strong enemy and famine for three years after its ships had been taken—this city was now being utterly blotted out and destroyed. As Scipio looked on he is said to have wept and openly to have lamented the enemy’s fate. For a long while he remained sunk in thought, reflecting that the fortunes of all cities and peoples and empires, like of those of individuals, must change. Troy had fallen, once so prosperous a city; the empires of the Assyrians, and the Medes, and the Persians after them, had fallen, and so, lately, the Macedonian empire, the most brilliant of them all. 
Source: Appian, The Destruction of Carthage. Source: http://www.livius.org/ap-ark/appian/appian_punic_27.html

q=0.01', } r = requests.get(url, headers=headers) r.raise_for_status() r.encoding = r.apparent_encoding return r.text def getDailyNews(self) -> list[dict[str, Union[str, list[dict[str, str]]]]]: # yyyy-mm-dd 格式化当天日期 # formatted_date = datetime.now().strftime("%Y-%m-%d") current_date = datetime.now() for i in range(365): new_date = current_date - timedelta(days=i) formatted_date =new_date.strftime("%Y-%m-%d") print(formatted_date ) naviUrl = f'https://www.shobserver.com/staticsg/data/journal/{formatted_date}/navi.json' try: naviData = json.loads(self.fetch(naviUrl)) newsPages = naviData["pages"] print(f'「解放日报」正在处理 {formatted_date} 的 {len(newsPages)} 版新闻...') news = [] for newsPage in newsPages: pageName = newsPage["pname"] pageNo = newsPage["pnumber"] articleList = newsPage["articleList"] print( f'「解放日报」{pageNo} 版 - {pageName} 共有 {len(articleList)} 条新闻') for article in articleList: title = article["title"] subtitle = article["subtitle"] aid = article["id"] # 使用正则丢弃 title 含有广告的文章 if re.search(r'广告', title): continue articleContent, articlePictures = self.getArticle( formatted_date, pageNo, aid) news.append({ "id": f'{formatted_date}_{pageNo}-{aid}', "title": title, "subtitle": subtitle, "content": articleContent, "pictures": articlePictures }) return news except Exception as e: print(f'「解放日报」新闻列表获取失败！\n{e}') return [] def getArticle(self, date, pageNo, aid) -> tuple[str, list[object]]: articleUrl = f'https://www.shobserver.com/staticsg/data/journal/{date}/{pageNo}/article/{aid}.json' articleData = json.loads(self.fetch(articleUrl))["article"] articleContent = BeautifulSoup(articleData["content"], 'html.parser') # 转换
为 \n for br in articleContent.find_all("br"): br.replace_with("\n") articlePictures = [] articlePictureJson = json.loads(articleData["pincurls"]) for articlePicture in articlePictureJson: url = articlePicture["url"] name = articlePicture["name"] author = articlePicture["author"] ttile = articlePicture["ttile"] articlePictures.append({ "url": url, "alt": ttile, "title": ttile, "source": name, "author": author }) print( f'「解放日报」已解析 {pageNo} 版 - {articleData["title"]} | 字数 {len(articleContent)} | 图片 {len(articlePictures)} 张' ) return articleContent.get_text(), articlePictures jfdaily_spider = Main() if __name__ == '__main__': spider = Main() news = spider.getDailyNews() print(news) 如何获取每一天的数据并转换为json

My involvement in the instrumental music club reached new heights in Grade 10. We were constantly practicing new pieces and expected to perform regularly at school events. One particular event stands out, as our club was preparing to take the stage and I would be showcasing a brand new piece on the accordion. However, due to my poor time management, I found myself scrambling to learn the piece just a few days before the performance. This unfamiliarity with the fingerings filled me with self-doubt, and I even contemplated backing out of the performance. However, the thought of letting down my fellow musicians was unbearable.

After a night of agonizing over my decision, I came to the realization that dwelling in self-doubt would not solve anything. I made a firm resolution to never give up and decided to catch up with the rest of the group’s level through intense practice in just three days. Determined, I woke up before my alarm even went off and immediately rushed to the music room to begin practicing. Over those three days, I isolated myself from distractions and dedicated all of my free time to mastering the piece. It was during this time that our club president noticed my dedication and arranged for a classmate in the same section to practice with me. This practice partner provided immense support and encouragement, allowing me to pour my heart and soul into mastering the piece.

When the moment of truth arrived, I sat on stage with my team, confidently running my fingers across the accordion keys, fully immersed in the performance. Like a well-oiled machine, I flawlessly executed the piece, leaving the audience breathless with the complexity of the melody. We conquered the stage!

From this experience, I learned the vital importance of good time management, thorough preparation, and collaboration within a team. These key elements are the foundation of success, and I also discovered that strong leadership is the key that unlocks the door to achievement.

import torch from torch.utils.data import DataLoader from datasets import Dataset, DatasetDict import pandas as pd import random from transformers import AutoModelForCausalLM, AutoTokenizer, DataCollatorForLanguageModeling

model = "Qwen/Qwen1.5-1.8B" tokenizer = AutoTokenizer.from_pretrained(model) model = AutoModelForCausalLM.from_pretrained(model) tokenizer.pad_token = tokenizer.eos_token

from datasets import load_dataset prefix_token = "<fim_prefix>" middle_token = "<fim_middle>" suffix_token = "<fim_suffix>" eot_token = "" context_length = 512 chunk_length = context_length max_len = context_length ds_train = load_dataset("huggingface-course/codeparrot-ds-train", split="train") ds_valid = load_dataset("huggingface-course/codeparrot-ds-valid", split="validation") raw_datasets = DatasetDict( { "train": ds_train.shuffle().select(range(50000)), "valid": ds_valid.shuffle().select(range(500)), } )

def split_document(doc, fim_rate=0.5):

if random.random() < fim_rate:

length = len(doc)

prefix_len = random.randint(0,length)

suffix_len = random.randint(0, length - prefix_len)

middle_len = length - prefix_len - suffix_len

prefix = doc[:prefix_len]

middle = doc[prefix_len:prefix_len+middle_len]

suffix = doc[prefix_len+middle_len:]

return prefix, middle, suffix

else:

return doc, None, None

def format_psm(prefix, middle, suffix, tokenizer): fromatted_examle = f"{prefix_token}{prefix}{suffix_token}{suffix}{middle_token}{middle}{eot_token}" return formatted_examle

def format_spm(prefix, middle, suffix, tokenizer): fromatted_examle = f"{prefix_token}{suffix_token}{suffix}{middle_token}{prefix}{middle}{eot_token}" return formatted_examle

def format_nofim(doc, tokenizer): formatted_examle = f"{doc}" return formatted_examle

def apply_fim_transformation(chunk_list, p_psm=0.5): transformed_docs = [] for chunk in chunk_list: prefix, middle, suffix = split_document(chunk) if middle is not None: if random.random() < p_psm: transformed_doc = format_psm(prefix, middle, suffix, tokenizer) else: transformed_doc = format_spm(prefix, middle, suffix, tokenizer) transformed_docs.append(transformed_doc) else: transformed_doc = format_nofim(chunk, tokenizer) transformed_docs.append(transformed_doc) return transformed_docs

def join_transformed_chunk_docs(transformed_chunk_docs): merged_docs = transformed_chunk_docs[0] if len(transformed_chunk_docs) == 1: return merged_docs for i in range(2, len(transformed_chunk_docs)): merged_docs = merged_docs + eot_token + transformed_chunk_docs[i] return merged_docs

def apply_context_level_fim(chunk):

chunk_docs = chunk.split(eot_token)

transformed_chunk_docs = apply_fim_transformation(chunk_docs)

joined_transformed_chunk_docs = join_transformed_chunk_docs(transformed_chunk_docs)

# Return the transformed text directly

return joined_transformed_chunk_docs

class FimDataset(Dataset): def __init__(self, data): self._data = data def __len__(self): return len(self._data) def __repr__(self): return f"Dataset(num_rows={len(self)})" def __getitem__(self, index): chunk = self._data[index]["content_chunk"] chunk = str(chunk) return apply_context_level_fim(chunk)

train_dataset = FimDataset(chunk_ds["train"])

valid_dataset = FimDataset(chunk_ds["valid"])

以SCI的标准帮我用英文翻译下面这段话：为进一步分析缺口损伤对总压比的影响，图13展示了设计流量下，正常叶片和6种缺口损伤转子叶片的出口截面总压比沿径向分布情况。如图13所示，转子叶片前缘发生缺口损伤的时候，压气机的总压比在整个叶片高度范围都会有不同程度的下降，并且在发生缺口损伤的叶片高度，总压比会产生更明显的下降。而在除缺口存在叶片高度外的其余全部叶片高度范围，总压比的下降程度都会相应的减弱，这说明转子叶片前缘的缺口损伤对压气机全叶片高度的流动都有影响。而转子叶片后缘发生缺口损伤时，只在发生缺口损伤的相应叶片高度，压气机总压比会发生轻度下降，在其余的叶片高度范围总压比几乎不发生改变。在叶片后缘发生缺口的情况中，对于转子叶片后缘中部发生缺口时，根据前文所述的损伤叶片气动参数下降规律，可知此位置的缺口造成压气机各项气动参数的下降程度都为最小，几乎与正常叶片保持一致。所以按照转子叶片出口截面总压比沿径向分布的变化趋势，转子叶片后缘中部发生缺口损伤时，会引起其缺口位置上方和下方小部分区域总压比略微上升，但不会影响总压比在全叶片高度总压比降低的趋势。此外，通过观察发现，发生在相同叶片高度范围的缺口导致压气机的总压比变化趋势相同，而缺口发生在叶片前缘时相较于叶片后缘，叶片前缘发生缺口时，会使压气机全叶片高度的总压比下降程度更为严重。

summarize this:
The resource constrained project scheduling problem with a flexible project structure and consumption
and production of resources, involves making a selection of activities and scheduling these activities in
order to minimize the makespan, subject to precedence and resource constraints. Since finding a feasible selection of activities is NP-hard, we introduce the concept of group graphs and restrict ourselves
to instances with an acyclic group graph. For these instances, which represent many practical cases, we
show how to make a feasible selection of activities in polynomial time and use this concept to schedule
the selected activities using a hybrid differential evolution algorithm. We compare this algorithm with
an algorithm from the literature on special cases of instances without consumption and production of resources, and show that our algorithm creates solutions of higher quality. Furthermore, to compare general
instances, we develop an ant colony optimization algorithm that performs slightly better on special cases
than the algorithm from literature and show that the hybrid differential evolution algorithm outperforms
the ant colony optimization algorithm on general instances

(In the school literature clubroom…)

Monika: “Natsuki, are you okay?”

(Natsuki grips her belly tightly as another contraction hits her.)

Natsuki: (gritting her teeth) “Yeah…I’m fine…just a little…” (winces) “Uncomfortable…”

Monika: (concerned) “Are you sure? We should call for help or get you to a hospital.”

Natsuki: (taking a deep breath) “No, it’s okay. This is just Braxton Hicks. It’s normal during pregnancy.” (tries to relax her muscles)

Monika: (still worried) “But Natsuki, you’re in so much pain. Maybe it’s best to be safe and get checked out.”

Natsuki: (smiling weakly) “I appreciate your concern, Monika, but I’ve talked to my doctor about it. They said it’s normal. I just need to breathe through it and wait for them to pass.”

Sayori: (rushing in) “Guys! What’s going on?”

Monika: “Natsuki’s having contractions, but she insists it’s Braxton Hicks.”

Sayori: (looking concerned) “Are you sure? Maybe we should call an ambulance just in case.”

Natsuki: (holding onto her belly) “No, Sayori. Trust me, I’ve already talked to my doctor. It’s supposed to happen during the last trimester. It’s uncomfortable, but it’s not an emergency.”

Yuri: (entering the room with a worried expression) “I couldn’t help overhearing. Natsuki, are you certain about this? It might be safer to seek medical attention.”

Natsuki: (taking a deep breath) “I understand your concerns, Yuri, but I trust my doctor. They assured me these contractions are normal during pregnancy. I just have to bear with it until they subside.”

Monika: (placing a comforting hand on Natsuki’s shoulder) “If you’re sure, Natsuki, then we’ll support you through this. Just let us know if you need anything.”

Natsuki: (smiling gratefully) “Thanks, guys. I appreciate your concern, but I think I’ll be okay. We’ll continue the literature club meeting once these contractions p-” (gasps in pain)

Deep within the whispering forests of Eldoria, a mythical land hidden by the mists of time, Binky, the palm-sized wonder, embarked on her nightly escapades. As the moon cast silver beams through the forest canopy, her sparkling bush baby eyes scanned the underbrush for new adventures.

One tranquil night, Binky noticed a peculiar, glowing object nestled between the roots of an ancient oak. Her curiosity piqued, and her mouse-like nose twitched with excitement as she approached the mysterious artifact. It was an amulet, emitting a soft, golden light, and it seemed to beckon her with an otherworldly hum.

Despite her natural caution, Binky couldnt resist. She reached out with her tiny, adroit paws and touched the amulet. In a fleeting moment, she was surrounded by a swirl of colors, and the forest transformed around her. Binky had been granted an incredible gift: she could now understand and speak with the plants and trees around her.

As Binky frolicked through the forest, she learned from the flora around her – from the oldest oak to the youngest sapling. They told her tales of the forests past and shared the wisdom of nature. She was enthralled by stories of symbiosis and the delicate balance of the ecosystem.

One day, however, Binky overheard a sorrowful murmur among the trees. A new path was being cleared through the heart of the forest, threatening to disrupt the harmony of their world. The trees were fearful, and their distress echoed throughout the woodland.

Recalling her delightful conversations and the wisdom imparted by her leafy friends, Binky knew she had to act. Using her newfound language, she communicated with a group of friendly humans who cherished the forest as much as she did. Together, they devised a plan to create a safe passage that would protect the forests heart while allowing humans to appreciate its beauty without causing harm.

Binkys bravery and unique ability to bridge the communication gap between humans and nature saved the forest. Through her efforts, she taught her human friends to listen to the whispers of the trees, fostering a deeper respect for the natural world.

As time went by and the story of the tiny, fluffy creatures heroism spread throughout Eldoria, Binky became a legend, a symbol of coexistence and understanding. And the great lesson she left behind was simple yet profound:

In every corner of the world, no matter how small or seemingly insignificant, every creature has a voice and a role to play in the tapestry of life. By listening to each other and working together, we can find harmony and preserve the precious balance of our shared planet., generate a title only, one liner string

Analyze the following text:

RAMPAGE

The game where the nice guys don't get a look in.

Grab your way through Chicago, punch up New York, and jump on San Francisco.

Three indescribably nasty characters which bear a remarkable likeness to King Kong, Godzilla and Wolf-man, need you to send them on a rampage in an enduring 768 days of destruction, through 85 different cities.

---

Playing the Game

To play the game, move your monster up and down buildings and through the town, punching and chomping as you go.

To climb the walls of a building, move right or left to approach it. Then move up to climb.

As you climb, you can punch huge gaping holes in the building, grab and chomp people out of it -- even snatch TVs, flower pots, and all kinds of yummy morsels. But remember, some of them can be quite hazardous to your health!

Picking Off Helicopters and Other Antagonists

Trashing cities wouldn't be as much fun if no one tried to stop you. But don't worry. They will.

Puny helicopters will try to lay into you with a round of machine gun fire. Just punch 'em right out of the air.

Soldiers will try to blast you off with rifles. Turn these pesky GIs into hors d'oeuvres. But stay away from the guy with the dynamite -- eating TNT will give you a bad case of indigestion.

Tanks, trolleys, trucks, taxis, boats, and police cars will scurry away in a panic. You can simply punch them out of commission.

Helpless pedestrians can't really hurt you. But don't let that stop you from devouring them.

Other Tasty Treats

In addition to those delectable helicopters and vehicles, there are other tasty little tidbits hidden throughout the game. Most of them can be found inside the buildings -- especially when the windows are open. And many of them must be gobbled up at just the right moment.

You'll gain valuable energy when you munch on the right thing at the right time. But you'll lose energy if you devour the wrong thing at the wrong time. There are other ways to gain and lose energy, too.

The following list shows which is which:

Gain Energy by Consuming:
people
soldiers
goldfish
toast when it's up
milk
bowls of fruit
watermelon
turkeys
hamburgers
another monster (after it's shrunk back into a human)
jugs of water

Lose Energy by:
eating poison
eating cactus
eating a candle
punching a toaster alone
eating dynamite
punching a light bulb when it's on
getting punched by another monster
getting shot
getting too close to explosions
punching a TV when it's on
falling off a building
falling into the water
being hit by thrown dynamite

Keep an Eye on Your Energy Level

The damage bar directly under your score lets you know how you're doing. And if you run out of energy completely, you'll automatically turn into a measly human. At which point you'll quickly find out who your true friends are.

What's the Point?

What makes having so much fun even more fun is that you get points for almost everything you punch or chomp throughout your escapade.

Here's what earns what:

Punching holes in buildings: 50-250 points each
Punching helicopters: 225
Punching other vehicles: 250-1000
Punching TV when off: 250-1000
Punching a train: 200
Picking up money: 250-1000 points each
Picking up a light bulb when off: 250-1000
Picking up safe: 250-1000
Picking flowers: 250-1000

It's L.A. Story meets Europe; a scene reminiscent of Steve Martin's musings on excessive, ridiculous coffee preferences
from his satirical 1991 film. Imagine the French, for example, consuming triple-shot2 soy milk lattes, the Italians downing3
almond mocha espressos, or perhaps the Swiss insisting upon half-caf skimmed macciattos? It seems unlikely to some,
but it may become a real possibility. That's because European nations, including Italy, which introduced the coffeehouse
to the world more than 400 years ago, now face an American challenge to this treasured4, and once unique, institution.
The Seattle-based coffee powerhouse, Starbucks, has announced plans to expand5 its 4,000-strong empire with some 650
branches6 planned for continental Europe.
Starbucks is currently opening new branches worldwide at a rate of three per day. "We're taking a softly, softly7 approach
when it comes to Europe," explained a spokeswoman for Starbucks Europe. "We expect to open shops in the big four
countries, Italy, Germany, France and Spain in the next 24 to 36 months." The company has had branches for some time
outside of the United States, in places as far and wide as Thailand, Dubai, and Saudi Arabia. In many of these countries,
Starbucks coffee struck8 its customers as being exotic, enticing, and addictive. The Japanese are particularly addicted to
the American import, with over 200 outlets serving customers throughout the country.
But now, Starbucks is attempting to encroach upon9 what Europe considers its own pride and joy10, something not to be
challenged by outside imitators. In Italy, where one city has already formed an association to protect historic cafés, a
battle lies ahead. For Italians, drinking their coffee is as routine as breathing, a recent survey11 found that 70 million cups
of espresso are drunk in Italy each year. That's 600 shots per person, consumed in any of Italy's 110,000 coffee bars.
Milan, nexus of the fashion world, has some 600 cafés alone. And Italians' cafés are a source of pride and joy. In this
country where sidewalk12 cafés are firmly entrenched13 in the national psyche, Starbucks' announcement has caused an
uproar14. "The Italian café is a culture that the Americans have repackaged15," said a spokesman for one of Starbucks'
European competitors. "They concentrate more on their image than the coffee." Italy's La Stampa newspaper said: "We
thought we had everything in Italy, but it turns out we lacked16 one thing: American coffee,"
It's not Starbucks' first foray17 into the European market. Just three years ago, the first Starbucks was opened at Britain's
Manchester Airport. There are now 200 stores in this country alone, with plans for an additional 140 outlets to open in
the next two years. But on the Continent, Starbucks may have a formidable challenge. Europeans like their coffee plain18
and simple; the Starbucks’ tradition of customized19, high-maintenance coffees just may not work in continental Europe.
Though Europeans may choose espressos instead of cappuccinos, having a coffee is a treasured break20, or perhaps a
leisurely start, for one's day. One Swiss newspaper writer dismissed21 Starbucks as "coffee culture in a cardboard cup."
Yet Starbucks has already ventured into Switzerland, where its three-storied Zurich shop attracts customers in one of 50
outlets planned for the alpine country. In fact, “The firm22 views Switzerland as a great test for continental Europe because
of the multi-cultural nature of the city," said the Starbucks Europe spokeswoman.
American coffee, à la Starbucks and other imitators, has been criticized for being weak and commercialized23. But the
company insists it has been welcomed with open arms on the Continent. And surprisingly, some European competitors
grudgingly credit Starbucks with opening the doors to Europe's espresso bar market. "The Europeans, in particular, are
quite pleasantly surprised when they taste Starbucks for the first time," Starbucks chairman Howard Schultz told the press
recently, "because American coffee has had a bad reputation for so long." The company maintains that it is taking into
account24 the local influences of the new Starbucks countries. Though the company owns almost all of its stores in the
States, Starbucks finds local business partners in most foreign markets. And while it doesn't change its coffee offerings,
the food choices are adapted to local cultures. "We don't believe we are an American company, but an international
brand," Howard Behar, president of Starbucks Coffee International recent told the BBC. In Britain, Starbucks hopes to
use the national pub culture to make Starbucks another meeting place, he added. But Starbucks' challenge will not only
be its ability to open and maintain branches world-wide, but to overturn25 decades, if not centuries, of tradition. Coffee is
already currently the second largest traded commodity in the world, just after oil. With Starbucks pushing into newer
territories faster than it can come up with new coffee variations, this trend looks set to continue


WRITE T
or F ON THE ANSWER SHEET PROVIDED
26 Everyone agrees that Starbucks will change the nature of coffee drinking on the European continent.
27 Starbuck’s has a global ‘empire’ of 650 branches.
28 This is not Starbucks’ first venture outside of the US.

30 However, Italian cafés are not seen as culturally different to Starbucks’ cafés.

while True:
  first_artist = random.choice(keys)
  second_artist = random.choice(keys)

  while first_artist == second_artist:

  while True:
    guess = input(f"\nWhich artist has more monthly Spotify listeners - 1. {first_artist.title()} or 2. {second_artist.title()}? ")

      score += 1
      break

    elif guess_lower == second_artist.lower() and artists_listeners[second_artist] > artists_listeners[first_artist]:
      print(f"You guessed correctly! {second_artist.title()} had {int(artists_listeners[second_artist] / 1e6):,}M monthly Spotify listeners and {first_artist.title()} has {int(artists_listeners[first_artist] / 1e6):,}M monthly Spotify listeners.")
      score += 1
      break

    else:
      print(f"\nSorry, you guessed incorrectly. {first_artist.title()} had {int(artists_listeners[first_artist] / 1e6):,}M monthly Spotify listeners and {second_artist.title()} has {int(artists_listeners[second_artist] / 1e6):,}M monthly Spotify listeners.\n")
      score = 0

      if play_again.lower() == 'n':
        print("Thanks for playing!")
        quit()

Paraphrase the following without reducing the word count

Literature has demonstrated that green human resource management (GHRM) increases social and economic well being of firms and their employees from a broad perspective while also raising knowledge of environmental challenges. It is helpful in reducing carbon footprints and costs, fostering employee productivity and environmental awareness (Ahmad, 2015). The green human resource management procedures could aid in boosting employees' productivity and dedication to enhance environmental efficiency (Krambia-Kapardis & Zopiatis, 2020; Delmas & Burbano, 2011, Chen, Paillé & Boiral, 2016).
 In addition, Muster and Schrader (2011) noted that companies, who adopted sustainable practices showed a competitive advantage in terms of cost savings and earnings. By implementing green supply chain strategies for a better living, further advantages in pollution prevention can be attained. Thus, using green business strategies benefits society as a whole and demonstrates the socially responsible side of businesses. 
Furthermore, it is evident that both in developed and developing nations, the manufacturing sector is regarded as a major contributor to many types of environmental pollution, necessitating a rigorous evaluation, monitoring, and correction of its managerial practices (Rehman et al., 2016). Due to the significant impact that the manufacturing sector has on a country's economic development, it is becoming more and more important to adopt environmentally friendly practices that can lessen the negative effects of this important industry on the environment (Szirmai and Verspagena, 2015; Marconi et al., 2016, Ng & Burke, 2010, Huang & Chen, 2020).
 The adoption of green practices is not restricted o a particular organizational department. Indeed, all employees in an organization's functions share equal responsibility for maintaining a green workplace (Opatha & Arulrajah, 2014). Hence, managers should involve all levels of their staff in practices for protecting the environment. 
The green human resource management (GHRM) approaches involve applying conventional HRM techniques in a way that is consistent with environmental goals and the firm's strategic HRM dimensions (Gholami et al., 2016). A variety of GHRM practices and phases have been proposed in various literature; for example, Milliman and Clair (2017) introduced four phases for an environmental HRM model, namely, providing an environmental vision, training employees in sharing environmental vision and goals, evaluating environmental performance of employees, and finally, rewarding employees for their environmental efforts through reward programs. Daily and Huang (2001) presented four components for the HRM framework for the environmental management system, including senior executive support, training, empowerment, and rewarding environmental HR.
According to Bangwal and Tiwari (2015), significant methods for preserving alignment between employees and the organization's environmental strategy include recruitment, performance management and reward policies and appraisal, training and development, employment relations, and pay and reward policies. Similarly, majority of research in literature described green human resource management activities as encompassing hiring and selection, training, performance management, compensation and reward structures, and involvement(Huang & Chen, 2020; Krambia-Kapardis & Zopiatis, 2020, Delmas & Burbano, 2011, Raza, Aziz & Ahmed, 2019, Tang et al., 2017).

(In the school literature clubroom…)

Sayori: “This isn’t making sense! Where’s MC?!”

Yuri: “I’m not entirely certain, but perhaps he’s been caught up with something unexpected. It’s not like MC to be late without at least sending a message.”

Natsuki: “Knowing him, he probably lost track of time. He can be so dense sometimes.”

(As my friends continue to talk, I couldn’t help but feel like they were getting a little ahead of themselves. So, as the club president, I had to step in.)

Monika: “Let’s not jump to conclusions, everyone. MC is usually responsible about these things. There might be a good reason he hasn’t shown up yet. Why don’t we give him a few more minutes? In the meantime, we can start our meeting and catch him up when he arrives.”

Sayori: “You’re right, Monika! We should stay positive!”

Yuri: “Indeed. It would be prudent to use our time efficiently while we await his arrival.”

Natsuki: “Fine. But he owes us an explanation!”

Monika: “Absolutely, we’ll ask him about it when he gets here. For now, let’s focus on today’s agenda. We were going to share some of our recent writing, weren’t we? Sayori, would you like to start us off with your poem?”

Sayori: “Okay, I guess I can do that. But it’s a little silly, I was hoping to get MC’s reaction to it…”

Yuri: “Sharing our writing is beneficial, regardless of who is present. Besides, sharing in a smaller group might allow for more detailed feedback.”

Natsuki: “Yeah, and maybe it’ll set the bar low for MC when he finally shows up and has to share his poem!”

(Sayori gets her poem out, a smile growing on her face.)

Monika: “That’s the spirit, everyone. I’m sure MC will join us soon. Let’s hear Sayori’s poem, and then we can each take a turn. I’m looking forward to hearing what you’ve all been working on!”

(As Sayori reads her poem, I couldn’t help but see that Natsuki looked very…angry. Well, she’s angry almost all week, but she’s never THIS angry.)

                if

                then
                    x : halve xs

According to Norquest (2007), Hlai, which also belongs to the Kra-Dai language family, is the largest minority language spoken in Hainan. Patterning with other Kra-Dai languages, oblique phrases also appear in the post-verbal position in Hlai. Therefore, it is very likely that Hainan Min undergoes contact with Hlai, as argued by Zeng (2023), which results in the use of post-verbal oblique phrases in Hainan Min. The immigrant languages demonstrate similar phenomena as well. For instance, the optional usage between finite and non-finite subordinate clauses in Dutch Turkish (see Valk & Backus 2013). Subordination is predominantly non-finite in Turkish (see Göksel & Kerslake 2005). However, the Turkish immigrants in the Netherlands do not have such a preference on non-finite expressions, contrary to their homeland monolingual speakers. In an elicited imitation task, the Dutch Turkish produces a nearly equal number of finite (48%) and non-finite (52%) subordinate clause whereas the Turkish monolinguals clearly prefer the non-finite type (73%) over the finite type (27%). Valk & Backus (2013) conclude that this change is due to the contact between Dutch and Turkish in that subordination in Dutch only appears in finite form for the corresponding sentences in Turkish. To summarize, in this section, we demonstrate that pre-verbal and post-verbal adverbs in Wu are both first-merged independently in the structure. The targeted apparent optional constructions are resulted from the contact between Wu and Mandarin. As the model language, if the influence of Mandarin continues, the post-verbal adverbs in Wu may fade away in the end, which is exactly the case for the north-western sub-varieties in Wu. Furthermore, the current study suggests that optional constructions are one of the plausible outputs when two minimally different grammars are in contact.

import json
import argparse
from docx import Document
from typing import Dict, List

def read_notebook(path: str) -> Dict:
    with open(path, encoding='utf8') as f:
        file = json.load(f)
    return file

def parse_notebook(file: Dict) -> Document:
    document = Document()
    for cell in file['cells']:
        if cell['cell_type'] == 'markdown':
            paragraph = parse_cell(cell['source'])
            document.add_paragraph(paragraph)
    return document

def parse_cell(lines: List) -> str:
    paragraph = ''
    for line in lines:
        if "![" not in line: # drop pictures
            paragraph += line
    return paragraph

def main():
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description='Process command line arguments.')
    parser.add_argument('--path', type=str, help='notebook path for parsing')
    args = parser.parse_args()
    path = args.path

    file = read_notebook(path)
    document = parse_notebook(file)
    document.save('docx_file.docx')

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

players_dict = {player['id']: player for player in bootstrap_data["elements"]}
teams_dict = {team['id']: team['name'] for team in bootstrap_data["teams"]}

# الحصول على بيانات اللاعبين المباشرة للجولة 24

fixtures_data = requests.get(fixtures_url).json()

print(f"Results for Gameweek {event_id}:\n")

for fixture in fixtures_data:
    # ترجمة أرقام الفرق إلى أسمائها
    team_h = teams_dict.get(fixture['team_h'], "Unknown")
    team_a = teams_dict.get(fixture['team_a'], "Unknown")
    team_h_score = fixture['team_h_score']
    team_a_score = fixture['team_a_score']

    print(f"Fixture: {team_h} vs {team_a} - Score: {team_h_score}-{team_a_score}")

    # استخراج بيانات اللاعبين
    for player in event_data["elements"]:
        player_id = player["id"]
        player_stats = player["stats"]
        player_explains = player.get('explain', [])

        # إذا كان اللاعب قد سجل أهدافًا، قدم تمريرات حاسمة (أسيست)، أو حصل على بونص في هذه المباراة
        if any(explain["fixture"] == fixture['id'] for explain in player_explains):
            if player_stats["goals_scored"] > 0 or player_stats["assists"] > 0 or player_stats["bonus"] > 0:
                # الحصول على اسم اللاعب
                player_name = players_dict.get(player_id, {}).get("web_name", "Unknown")

                print(f"Player: {player_name}, Goals: {player_stats['goals_scored']}, "
                      f"Assists: {player_stats['assists']}, Bonus: {player_stats['bonus']}")

import cv2
import tkinter as tk
from tkinter import messagebox
from datetime import datetime
from PIL import Image, ImageTk

import os
import pickle
import face_recognition

def load_known_faces(folder_path):
    known_faces = []
    known_names = []

    for name in os.listdir(folder_path):
        person_folder = os.path.join(folder_path, name)
        if not os.path.isdir(person_folder):
            continue

        for image_name in os.listdir(person_folder):
            image_path = os.path.join(person_folder, image_name)
            image = face_recognition.load_image_file(image_path)
            image_encoding = face_recognition.face_encodings(image)
            if len(image_encoding) > 0:
                known_faces.append(image_encoding[0])
                known_names.append(image_name)  # Save the image name
                known_names.append(name)  # Save the person name

    return known_faces, known_names



def recognize_faces(camera_id, known_faces, known_names):
    video = cv2.VideoCapture(camera_id)

    while True:
        ret, frame = video.read()

        # Определение лиц на кадре
        face_locations = face_recognition.face_locations(frame)
        face_encodings = face_recognition.face_encodings(frame, face_locations)

        for face_encoding, face_location in zip(face_encodings, face_locations):
            matches = face_recognition.compare_faces(known_faces, face_encoding)
            name = " "

            # Поиск соответствия лица с известными лицами
            if True in matches:
                first_match_index = matches.index(True)
                name = known_names[first_match_index]

            # Рисуем прямоугольник вокруг лица и название
            top, right, bottom, left = face_location
            cv2.rectangle(frame, (left, top), (right, bottom), (0, 255, 0), 2)
            cv2.putText(frame, name, (left, bottom + 20), cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_SIMPLEX, 1, (0, 255, 0), 2)

        # Отображение кадра с распознанными лицами
        cv2.imshow("“Face Recognition”", frame)

        if cv2.waitKey(1) & 0xFF == ord('q'):
            break

    video.release()
    cv2.destroyAllWindows()


# Создание окна для отображения
window = tk.Tk()
window.title("“Face Recognition”")
window.geometry("800x600")

# Загрузка известных лиц
known_faces, known_names = load_known_faces("database")

# function to extract the text from row td elements and create a row vector 
extract_td_text <- function(row) {
  td_elements <- html_children(row)
  td_texts <- sapply(td_elements, html_text)
  td_texts <- trimws(td_texts)
  return(as.vector(td_texts))
}

  data_df <- data_list[[k]]
  merge_df <- df_list[[k]]
  
  if (nrow(merge_df) == 0) {
    next
  }
  
  new_row <- data_df[1,] # Create a new row based on the structure of the data_ dataframe
  
  # Set all values in the new row to NA except the protocol_url_segment column
  new_row[,-1] <- NA 
  new_row$protocol_url_segment <- protocol_url_segment 
  
  # Define the starting codes for new entries
  starting_codes <- c("B.1.1", "D.1.2andD.1.3", "G.4.1")
  
  entry_counter <- 1 # Initialize entry counter
  
  # Loop through each row in the df_ dataframe
  for (i in 1:nrow(merge_df)) {
    code <- merge_df[i, 1]
    value <- merge_df[i, 3]
    
    # Check if the code exists in the data_ dataframe
    if (code %in% colnames(data_df)) {
      # If the code is a starting code of a new entry and it is not the first row 
      # then add the current new_row to the data_ dataframe and create a new new_row
      if (code %in% starting_codes && i > 1) {
        # Assign the entry counter value to the corresponding column
        if (k == 2) { # data_B
          new_row$sponsor_number <- entry_counter
        } else if (k == 3) { # data_D
          new_row$IMP_number <- entry_counter
        } else if (k == 6) { # data_G
          new_row$network_number <- entry_counter
        }
        data_list[[k]] <- rbind(data_list[[k]], new_row)
        new_row <- data_df[1,]
        new_row[,-1] <- NA
        new_row$protocol_url_segment <- protocol_url_segment
        entry_counter <- entry_counter + 1 # Increment the entry counter
      }
      # Insert the value at the corresponding column in the new row
      new_row[, code] <- value
    }
  }
  
  # Assign the entry counter value to the corresponding column in the last new_row
  if (k == 2) { # data_B
    new_row$sponsor_number <- entry_counter
  } else if (k == 3) { # data_D
    new_row$IMP_number <- entry_counter
  } else if (k == 6) { # data_G
    new_row$network_number <- entry_counter
  }
  
  # Add the last new row to the data_ dataframe
  data_list[[k]] <- rbind(data_list[[k]], new_row)
}

# Update the data_ dataframes with the merged values

润色如下内容：As Confucius said: “Choose a job you love, and you will never have to work a day in your life.” This quote made me realise the importance of choosing the right profession and what impact this choice would have on my life.

I developed an interest in the field of accounting through my exposure to it at undergraduate level. We have analysed and interpreted financial statements of various companies like: Cashbuild and Enron. This has given me the opportunity to explore the basics of bookkeeping and to see how organisations function, within the corporate world. What is fascinating about accounting as a profession is that it is multi-faceted and one can easily move into fields linked to it namely: banking, taxation, insurance and auditing. It is also very interesting how one cannot only use accounting rules to control and drive systems within an organisation but also to steer companies out of an economic crisis. Therefore, I look forward to being part of this dynamic field of study and ensuring that the company I work for in the future is on the correct path towards financial stability and security.

To get prepared for my future studies in accounting, I undertook a variety of relevant courses. Through the process of learning, I have mastered the basic theoretical knowledge of accounting,economics and finance, and learned the qualitative and quantitative analysis methods, which will be highly beneficial to my research. In addition, paying attention to various financial and economic news to keep abreast of the theoretical frontiers and development trends of this discipline is one of my other favourite events, which greatly enhanced my knowledge of empirical operations of accounting to some degree.Many other events such as attending workshops,reading books of accounting and finance,and conducting empirical research on accounting operation also assisted me to strengthen my ability to utilize theories in practice.

As for my career planning,I would like to be a professional accountant focusing on tax administration in a Big Four firm in order to apply what I have learned into practice and make possible contributions. After several years of experience, it is ideal for me to become a manager to make sound and strategic business decisions and cooperate with more talents with different backgrounds for a better career prospect.

I have chosen to study in Australia for the following three reasons. Firstly, in my opinion, Australia has the best universities in the world and being accepted in the University of Melbourne will help me realise my dream of becoming an accountant. Secondly, studying in Australia will open many doors in my career and I will be able to work there and therefore gain valuable experience. The third reason is that I enjoy meeting new people and discovering new things, hence I believe that studying in Australia will make me a more open-minded and motivated individual.

            skip_full_frame_catalog = False
            for classification in first_frame.classifications.classifications:
                start, stop, step = 0, sample.metadata.total_frame_count, 1

                if classification.label == "video_split":
                    start, stop = classification.start, classification.stop
                elif classification.label == "single_frames":
                    start, stop, step = classification.start, classification.stop, classification.step
                else:
                    continue
                frame_ids_for_classification = [
                    frame.id for frame in sample.frames.values()
                    if start <= frame.frame_number <= stop and (frame.frame_number - start) % step == 0
                ]

                if frame_ids_for_classification:
                    classification_view = session.view.select_frames(frame_ids_for_classification)
                    classification_views.append(classification_view)
                    skip_full_frame_catalog = True

            if skip_full_frame_catalog:
                continue

        start, stop, step = 0, sample.metadata.total_frame_count, 1
        frame_ids_for_default = [
            frame.id for frame in sample.frames.values()
            if start <= frame.frame_number <= stop and (frame.frame_number - start) % step == 0
        ]

        if frame_ids_for_default:
            default_view = session.view.select_frames(frame_ids_for_default)
            classification_views.append(default_view)
